title: Chametz
summary:
Key ideas
- A person encounters a vampire who claims to be Jewish and wants to drink their blood
- The person tries to use their knowledge of Jewish dietary laws to dissuade the vampire
- The vampire ultimately overpowers the person and drinks their blood

Key learnings
- Knowledge of Jewish dietary laws can be useful in unexpected situations
- Trying to distract and buy time can be a useful tactic in potentially dangerous situations
- Sometimes even the best-laid plans can fail in the face of overwhelming force

Key questions
- What would have happened if the person had been able to convince the vampire of their argument?
- Is it possible for a vampire to be Jewish, considering that they are undead entities and not technically alive? 
- Does the encounter with the vampire change the person's religious practices or attitudes in any way?
